Award.AwardTitle: BARD workshop on Microbial virulence determinants and plant innate immunity: Tel Aviv University, Tel Aviv, Israel, February 5th-9th, 2012
Award.AbstractNarration: The objective of the workshop is to facilitate the exchange of information among leading scientists investigating the interplay between microbial pathogens and the plant immune system. The participants will address two fundamental questions pertaining to the molecular determinants that impact plant disease in agriculture: 1) What are the critical plant immune pathways that inhibit pathogen growth and how are they regulated? 2) What are the mechanisms by which pathogens suppress plant immunity to persist in plants? Scientists from the US, Israel, Europe and China using diverse tools and approaches to study plant-microbe interactions will participate in the workshop. The workshop will provide an interactive platform to share technology, establish collaboration, and develop innovative technology to improve plant health, productivity and security. Participants will: (1) critically review the status of research and technology in the field; (2) address the agricultural impacts of biotechnology aimed to improve plant disease resistance in the US and Israel; (3) assess biotechnology and set priorities for future research in this area; and (4) assemble integrated teams to develop novel research programs to combat plant pathogens in the field. The workshop will advance discovery in the early cell biology and signal transduction events that cover plant immune responses in model and natural hosts. The workshop design will provide a unique format for participants to critically evaluate the challenges and roadblocks that impede research progress. Students will be active participants. They will gain knowledge and feedback from leading scientists while providing a fresh perspective for future work. Several participants have links to companies working on agricultural technology development. Student exposure to the infrastructure and goals of business models will be educational for their professional development for industry-related work. Special attention has been made to promote participation of women and minorities actively working in this area.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project:

BARD worshop on “Microbial virulence determinants and plant innate immunity” at Tel Aviv University, Tel Aviv, Israel, February 5-9th, 2012.

 

Organizing committee:

Dr. Mary Beth Mudgett – Stanford University, Stanford CA USA

Dr. Adi Avni – Tel Aviv University, Tel Aviv, Israel

Dr. Guido Sessa – Tel Aviv University, Tel Aviv, Israel

 

Funding sources:

The workshop was funded by BARD (the US-Israel Binational Research and Development Fund), NSF, the Company of Biologists, Protalix Biotherapeutics, Evogene, Kaiima, Danyel Biotech, Danziger innovations, Manna Center for Plant Biosciences, and Rahan Meristem.

 

Participants:

The workshop included senior research scientists and students from Israel, US, Germany, China, Netherlands, and France.

 

Research and education activities:

The overall objective of the workshop was to facilitate the exchange of information among leading scientists investigating the interplay between microbial pathogens and the plant immune system. We addressed two fundamental questions pertaining to the molecular determinants that impact plant disease in agriculture: 1) What are the critical plant immune pathways that inhibit pathogen growth and how are they regulated? 2) What are the mechanisms by which pathogens directly suppress plant immunity to persist in plant hosts? Established scientists and young students from the US, Israel, Germany, China, Netherlands, and France participated in the three-day workshop which was held at Tel Aviv University. The workshop consisted of short talks, a poster session, coffee breaks for extensive discussion, and shared meals to promote networking. We addressed four specific objectives: 1) We critically reviewed the current status of research and technology in the field with an emphasis on the modes of action of microbial virulence determinants and on plant strategies for the detection of invading pathogens and the induction of plant immune responses. 2) We addressed the agricultural impacts of current biotechnology aims to improve plant disease resistance in the US and Israel. 3) We assessed the current biotechnology and set priorities for future research in this area of plant-microbe interactions. 4) We assembled integrative teams to establish and reinforce collaborations aimed to develop novel research programs and technology to combat plant pathogens in the field.

 

Findings:

Current status of research - The primary focus of current research has been on the isolation and characterization of the plant signaling proteins involved with PAMP-triggered immunity and effector-triggered plant immunity. Researchers reported new genetic screens, proteomic approaches, and cell biology tools to characterize plant defense responses during infection. The biochemical study of pathogen effectors has been useful strategy to identify plant immune regulators and the key nodes in the plant immune system that are modulated during infection. 

 

Priorities for future research - Use of model plant systems has provided key insight to the components of plant immune system; however, coordinated research aimed to identify such components in agriculturally relevant plants was considered a priority. Adoption of the new technology and screens that were reported via new collaboration was considered essential for understanding the dynamic regulation of plant immune responses.
